questions.text: A 30-year-old man came to the OPD with a febrile illness of 2 days, associated with abdominal tenderness, malaise and diarrhoea. His temperature was 39 °C, PR- 78 bpm, BP- 110/70 mmHg. He lives in a crowded neighborhood with poor sanitation where many others have reported similar complaints recently. Which of the following  investigations will be the most appropriate choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's history of fever with relative bradycardia, abdominal tenderness, and similar cases in the neighborhood suggests enteric fever. It is caused by Salmonella typhi or paratyphi. Out of the given options, blood culture is the most sensitive test in this patient.

Diagnosis of enteric fever:

  • Blood culture: It is more sensitive during 1st week than in the subsequent weeks. It rapidly becomes negative on treatment with antibiotics.

  • Antibody testing: WIDAL test to detect rising titres of H and O agglutinins against salmonella typhi and paratyphi. Agglutinins appear by the end of the first week and rise steadily up to the 3rd or 4th week, after which they disappear.

  • Stool culture: It yields positive results from the 3rd week onwards.

  • Urine culture: Results may be positive after the 2nd week.

  • Bone marrow culture remains positive for 5 days even after the start of antibiotics and is the most sensitive test in the first week. The culture of duodenal aspirate may yield positive results when bone marrow culture is inconclusive.

Relative bradycardia is seen when patients have a lower heart rate than expected for a given rise in body temperature. (Faget's sign)

Infectious causes of relative bradycardia include: 

  • Salmonella typhi
  • Francisella tularensis
  • Coxiella burnetii (Q fever)
  • Leptospira interrogans
  • Legionella pneumophila
  • Rickettsia spp.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi (scrub typhus)
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • Plasmodium spp. (malaria)

Noninfectious causes include:

  • Drug fever 
  • Beta-blocker use 
  • Central nervous system lesions
  • Malignant lymphoma
  • Factitious fever

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady who is a known diabetic has had right shoulder pain for the past 7 months. She had pain initially mainly on external rotation along with restricted movements. Now, her pain has gradually decreased but she still complains of a stiff shoulder. You diagnose her with adhesive capsulitis. What stage of adhesive capsulitis is this patient in?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of decrease in pain and complaints of stiffness in the shoulder joint indicate stage II of adhesive capsulitis/frozen shoulder.

Frozen shoulder is a disorder characterized by progressive pain and stiffness of the shoulder, which usually resolves spontaneously. The condition is particularly associated with diabetes, Dupuytren’s contracture, hyperlipidemia, thyroid disorders, cardiac disease, and hemiplegia. X-ray of the shoulder is usually normal, with some cases showing sclerosis on the outer edge of the greater tuberosity.

Reeves classified the frozen shoulder into three stages:

  • Stage I (Stage of pain): In this stage patients usually complain of acute pain with decreased movements (external rotation is most affected followed by the abduction and then forward flexion; internal rotation is the least affected). This stage lasts for 10-36 weeks
  • Stage II: The stage of stiffness where pain gradually decreases and patients complain of the stiff shoulder. This lasts for 4 to 12 months.
  • Stage III: The stage of recovery, the patient will have no pain and the movements have recovered except that the movements are never regained back to normal. It usually lasts for 6 months to 2 years.

questions.text:
Which among the following muscles are bipennate muscles?
  1. Palmar interossei
  2. Dorsal interossei
  3. Flexor pollicis longus
  4. Flexor hallucis longus
  5. Rectus femoris
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the bipennate muscles are dorsal interossei, flexor hallucis longs and rectus femoris (2,4,5)

Muscles with oblique fibers are subclassified as follows:

  • Triangular: They are triangular in shape. E.g., temporalis, adductor longus, trapezius
  • Pennate: They are feather-shaped. Based on their complexity, they can have the following subtypes:
    • Unipennate: Fascicles on one side of the tendon. E.g.,
      • Flexor pollicis longus
      • Extensor digitorum longus
      • Peroneus tertius
      • Palmar interossei
    • Bipennate: Fascicles on two sides of the tendon. E.g., 
      • Rectus femoris,
      • Peroneus longus,
      • Flexor hallucis longus,
      • Dorsal interossei
    • Multipennate: Central tendon branches into two or more branches within the muscle. E.g.,
      • Deltoid
      • Subscapularis
    • Circumpennate (radial): Muscle fibers converge to a central tendon in a radial fashion. E.g.,
      • Tibialis anterior

Related Pearl: Classification of muscles according to their shape/direction of muscle fibers

Muscles with parallel fasciculi

Muscles with oblique fasciculi

Muscles with spiral or twisted fasciculi

Triangular: Temporalis, Adductor longus, 

Spiral: Pectoralis major, Latissimus dorsi, Supinator and Trapezius

questions.text: A 21-year-old college student is brought to the doctor by his family because they found him working in a "drag-queen" bar, dressed as a woman. He says that he feels beautiful when he dresses as a woman and wears make-up. He likes the idea of feeling like a woman but has no wish to undergo any sex change surgery. He does not wish to live with his family as they are not supportive of his choices. This is punishable under which IPC section?
questions.solution:
The condition described in the given scenario is dual-role transvestism, in which the person temporarily likes to identify with the opposite gender by dressing like them. This is not punishable by law.

It is not associated with any genital or hormonal abnormality. This condition is not a sexual paraphilia as it is not accompanied by sexual excitement derived from cross-dressing. They do not want to undergo sex change surgery as they are otherwise comfortable with leading a life as their assigned gender.

Terms related to gender incongruence:

  • Transsexualism is a condition where the person wants to live life as a member of the opposite sex. They often prefer to undergo sex change surgery.
  • Dual-role transvestism
  • Gender incongruence of childhood- persistent excessive preoccupation with the dressing and activities of the opposite sex and desire to be one among the members of the opposite sex. This is accompanied by distress with one's assigned gender.

Note: The terms "transsexualism" and "gender identity disorder of children," which were present in ICD-10, are now considered outdated, and the ICD-11 has renamed them as "gender incongruence of adolescence and adulthood" and "gender incongruence of childhood," respectively. This change reflects the current understanding that trans-related and gender-diverse identities are not mental illnesses and that labeling them as such can result in significant stigma.

Disorders of sexual preference:

  • Fetishism - Using nonliving objects, usually those belonging to the opposite sex, as stimuli for sexual gratification
  • Fetishistic transvestism - Dressing as the opposite sex to derive sexual pleasure
  • Voyeurism - Recurrent urge to observe a person while undressing or engaging in sexual activity
  • Pedophilia - Sexual preference for pre-pubertal or early pubertal children
  • Sadomasochism - Preference for inflicting pain on a sexual partner or being subjected to pain by the sexual partner.

Other options:

Option A: Section 294 IPC is related to exhibitionism. It involves behaviors over a period of 6 months or more involving the exposure of one’s genitals to an unsuspecting stranger. This is a punishable offense with imprisonment of up to 3 months or a fine.

Option C: Section 377 IPC: Definition and punishment of unnatural sexual offenses with imprisonment for life or up to 10 years and fine. In a landmark judgment, the Supreme Court of India scrapped the provisions of Section 377, except the provisions of bestiality, which is cruelty against animals.

Option D: Section 290 IPC is related to frotteurism, which describes behavior in which a person obtains sexual gratification by contact with another person (rubbing his private parts against female buttocks, breasts, thighs, etc. in crowds). This is a punishable offense, with a fine of up to 200 Rs.

questions.text:
Which among the following options depict the correct match between the substances (column A) and their site of production (column B)?
Column A Column B
i. 1, 25 dihydroxycholecalciferol a. Liver
ii. Erythropoietin b. Proximal tubule cells
iii. Angiotensinogen c. Juxtaglomerular cells
iv. Renin d. Interstitial cells in peritubular capillaries
questions.solution:
The correct match is (i-b), (ii-d), (iii-a), (iv-c).

Hormones produced by the kidney are:

1. Renin- It is produced by juxtaglomerular cells. It converts angiotensinogen to angiotensin I. Factors that affect renin secretion are:

Stimulatory Inhibitory

Increased sympathetic activity

 Increased afferent arteriolar pressure

Increased circulating catecholamines

 Angiotensin II
Prostaglandins Increased Na+ and Cl− reabsorption across macula densa
   Vasopressin

Conditions those increase renin secretion are:

  • Na+ depletion
  • Diuretics
  • Hypotension
  • Hemorrhage
  • Upright posture
  • Dehydration
  • Cardiac failure
  • Cirrhosis
  • Constriction of renal artery or aorta

2. Erythropoietin- the majority of the erythropoietin is produced from interstitial cells in the peritubular capillary bed of the kidneys. Some amount is produced by the perivenous hepatocytes in the liver. It is released in response to hypoxia, cobalt salts, and androgens. It increases red cell production.

3. 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol- The 25-hydroxycholecalciferol produced in the liver is further converted to 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol by the proximal tubular cells. This is also called calcitriol. It increases the calcium reabsorption from the kidneys, intestine, and increases the activity of osteoblasts.

Note- Angiotensinogen is synthesized in the liver. It is converted to angiotensin I by renin. Its circulating level is increased by glucocorticoids, thyroid hormones, estrogens, several cytokines, and angiotensin II.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient came to the physician with complaints of chronic back pain and easy fatigability.  An X-ray of his skull is shown below. Laboratory investigations show decreased hemoglobin, hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR. He should be started on which of the following combination therapy?
questions.solution:
This patient's history and clinical findings are suggestive of multiple myeloma. Lenalidomide +Bortezomib+Dexamethasone is the treatment of choice in multiple myeloma.

This patient's anemia, hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR are consistent with the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. The skull demonstrates the typical “punched out” lesions characteristic of multiple myeloma. 

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. Bone pain is the most common presenting symptom in multiple myeloma. The next most common clinical problem in patients with myeloma is susceptibility to bacterial infections. The most common infections are pneumonia and pyelonephritis, and the most frequent pathogens are Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Klebsiella pneumoniae in the lungs and Escherichia coli and other gram-negative organisms in the urinary tract.

Chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation prolongs overall survival in multiple myeloma patients.

The combination of lenalidomide, bortezomib, and dexamethasone achieves close to a 100% response rate making it one of the preferred induction regimens in transplant-eligible patients.

NOTE: The U.S. FDA has approved ABECMA, the first cell-based gene therapy to treat adult patients with multiple myeloma who have not responded to, or whose disease has returned after, at least four prior lines (different types) of therapy.

questions.text: A gross specimen of the colon obtained from a 14-year-old boy is shown below. Which of the following statements is false about this pathology?

choices.text: It occurs as a result of a defect in the DNA mismatch repair mechanism.
At least 100 polyps are needed to make the diagnosis.
Prophylactic colectomy is done for patients with APC mutations.
It is associated with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium.

questions.solution:
The gross specimen in the image shows the presence of multiple polyps in the colon, along with an area suspicious of colorectal carcinoma. Multiple polyps in the colon of a 14-year-old boy make familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) the likely diagnosis.

FAP is an autosomal dominant disorder that is caused by mutations of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene and not due to defects in the DNA repair mechanism. Defects in DNA mismatch repair genes result in hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer, MYH-associated polyposis, and some sporadic colon cancers.

Familial adenomatous polyposis, as the name suggests, is an inherited disorder presenting with numerous colorectal adenomatous polyps. It is an autosomal dominant disease caused by mutations in the APC gene, which is a regulator in the Wnt signaling pathway. At least 100 polyps are required to make a diagnosis of FAP. 

Patients are usually teenagers and multiple polyps are visible in the colon during sigmoidoscopy. It is associated with a variety of extraintestinal manifestations including congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigmental epithelium. Colorectal adenocarcinoma occurs in almost all cases before the age of 50. 

Prophylactic colectomy is recommended in patients with APC gene mutations. The surgeries used are colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA), restorative proctocolectomy with an ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (RPC), or total proctectomy and end ileostomy. The first 2 surgeries are preferred in young patients as it avoids a permanent stoma. 

Note- FAP along with brain tumors is called Turcot syndrome. FAP along with multiple osteomas, skin, and soft tissue tumors is called Gardner syndrome.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: Shweta came to donate blood for the first time on her 30th birthday. After an adequate history and baseline tests, blood donation was started along with the monitoring of her pulse and BP. She developed sweating,  bradycardia, hypotension, and fainted transiently. Which of the following should not be done?

choices.text: Help the patient to stand up on her feet
Give her fluids to drink orally
Avoid investigation for cause of fainting

questions.solution:
Helping the patient to stand on her feet should not be done.

The given scenario describes precipitation of vasovagal syncope. It might be due to anxiety in first time donor, a hot and humid environment in the donation room, or due to hypoglycemia, lack of sleep in the donor. Signs and symptoms are seen as pallor or sweating, slow pulse, drop in blood pressure, vomiting, loss of consciousness, or very rarely convulsions due to anoxia. 

What should be done in this situation?

• Discontinue donation
• Recline chair
• Loosen clothes
• Monitor BP and pulse
• Reassure the patient
• Give fluids to drink (recovery is usually rapid)

Since the patient underwent basic investigations, monitoring of the vitals before the procedure and she would recover immediately from vasovagal syncope, investigations for the cause of fainting are not necessary and can be avoided.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about pre-induction cervical ripening?
  1. Dinoprostone insert is placed in the posterior fornix.
  2. There should be a 4-6 hour interval between application of dinoprostone and starting oxytocin infusion
  3. Uterine tachysystole is common with >25mcg dose of misoprostol vaginal tablets
  4. Misprostol induces contractions in 30-60mins in most women
  5. The dinoprostone gel has a shorter induction to delivery time as compared to the insert
questions.solution:
Statements 1,3,4 are correct. 

The interval between application of dinoprostone gel and starting oxytocin infusion is 6-12 hours.

The dinoprostone insert has a shorter induction to delivery time as compared to the gel.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient, who was diagnosed with severe ARDS  was shifted to the intensive care unit and was put on mechanical ventilation with high PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure). This ventilatory setting results in all of the following nonpulmonary effects  except
questions.solution:
Mechanical ventilation with positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) setting results in all the above effects except decrease in Antidiuretic hormone level.

Positive end-expiratory pressure(PEEP)

PEEP is a mode of therapy used in conjunction with mechanical ventilation. Application of positive pressure during expiration as an adjunct to a mechanically ventilated breath is referred to as PEEP.

The principal mechanism of action appears to be the expansion of partially collapsed alveoli.

Pulmonary effects: 

  • In patients with decreased lung volume, appropriate levels of PEEP will increase FRC and tidal ventilation and thereby improving lung compliance.
  • It also helps in correcting ventilation/perfusion mismatch and aid in improving arterial oxygenation.

Nonpulmonary effects:

  • Urinary output decreases
  • Glomerular filtration decreases.
  • Circulating levels of antidiuretic hormone and angiotensin are usually elevated.
  • Central venous pressure increases
  • Progressive reductions in cardiac output
  • Decrease in both renal and hepatic blood flow.
  • Decreased free water clearance

questions.text: The radiologist performs  myocardial perfusion imaging  with  technetium-99m labeled compounds in a cardiac patient to determine the effectiveness of acute revascularization. Identify the true statement about technetium-99m.

choices.text: Pure beta emitter with half life of 12 hours
Pure gamma emitter with half life of 12 hours
Pure beta emitter with half life of 6 hours
Pure gamma emitter with half life of 6 hours

questions.solution:
Technetium-99m is a pure gamma emitter as it is in the metastable state and its half-life is  6 hours.

Technetium agents based on the Technetium-99m (Tc-99m) radioisotope are most frequently used an agent in medical imaging. The radioactive technetium can be chelated to a number of different compounds to create specific radiopharmaceuticals and optimise imaging of various structures.

Half-life of Tc 99m is 6 hours

Tc 99m produce gamma rays of 140 keV.

Note:

Myocardial perfusion imaging is done with either thallium-201 or technetium-99m labeled compounds (e.g., technetium-99m sestamibi).

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant was brought to you with hypotonia, a weak cough, and tongue fasciculations. A diagnosis of spinal muscular atrophy was made. Which of the following marked regions is affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The region marked 1 which shows the anterior horn of the spinal cord is affected in spinal muscular atrophy.

Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) is an autosomal recessive pattern disease characterized by progressive degeneration of the motor neurons. It results from a continuation of apoptosis that normally occurs in the embryonal period. This results in extensive neuronal degeneration and gliosis of the anterior horns of the spinal cord and brainstem motor nuclei.

Clinically SMA is classified into four types:

  • SMA type I/ Werdnig-Hoffmann disease
  • SMA type II
  • SMA type III/ Kugelberg-Welander disease
  • SMA type IV

SMA type I is seen before the age of six months. Children present with hypotonia, proximal muscle weakness, frog-leg posture, and tongue fasciculations. Involvement of the intercostal respiratory muscles causes a paradoxical abdominal breathing pattern and weak cough. Deep tendon reflexes are usually absent. It should be kept as one of the differential diagnoses for floppy infant syndrome.

SMA type II is seen between the age of 6-18 months. Children present with developmental delay, scoliosis, speech, and deglutition problems.

The proximal muscles involving the shoulder girdle are affected in SMA type III. Muscle hypertrophy might be present rather than atrophy.

SMA type IV (adult phenotype) presents with mild muscle weakness in the second or third decade of life. 

The gold standard for diagnosis is testing for SMN1 (survival motor neuron) gene deletion/ mutation. Supportive therapy enabling the patient to be maximally functionally independent is the mainstay in management.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with progressively worsening pain, redness in the right eye for the last two days. She has a history of sarcoidosis. On examination, the right eye is inflamed around the cornea, the pupil is constricted, and reacts sluggishly to light. The iris appears muddy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with progressively worsening eye pain and redness, constricted pupil reacting sluggishly to light, muddy iris, and a history of sarcoidosis is likely to have anterior uveitis. 

Sarcoidosis is a systemic inflammatory disorder characterized by the formation of non-caseating granulomas. Anterior uveitis is often a presenting symptom of sarcoidosis.

Anterior uveitis presents with blurred vision, pain, photophobia, circumcorneal conjunctival injection (around the limbus) with an aqueous flare and keratin precipitates. The pupil is constricted and reacts sluggishly to light. The clear pattern of the iris is lost and it appears muddy.

Slit-lamp examination shows the following signs in anterior uveitis:

Corneal signs: 

  • Keratic precipitates

Anterior chamber signs: 

  • Hypopyon
  • Aqueous cells
  • Aqueous flare
  • Deep and irregular anterior chamber due to posterior synechiae

Iris signs: 

  • Loss of normal pattern
  • Change in color "muddy iris"
  • Posterior synechiae

Pupillary signs: 

  • Constricted pupil
  • Irregular pupil shape
  • Ectropion of uveal pigment
  • Occlusion pupillae - blocked pupil due to extensive exudate

Steroids and cycloplegics are the mainstay of management for uveitis.

Cycloplegics

  • atropine
  • Relieves spasm of iris sphincter and ciliary muscle
  • Prevents the formation of synechiae

Steroids reduce inflammation by their anti-inflammatory effect 

Systemic therapy 

  • Steroids
  • NSAIDs
  • Immunosuppressants
    • Used in severe cases

Other options:

Option A: Acute bacterial conjunctivitis presents with pain, irritation, photophobia with hyperemia (pink eye), and purulent exudate. There is a diffuse conjunctival injection which is less seen in the circum-corneal region (as opposed to anterior uveitis)

Option C: Endophthalmitis is the infection of the intra-ocular cavities which presents with severe pain, loss of vision, and lid edema. It is usually seen in post-operative cases of ocular trauma (exogenous) and patients hospitalized with severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections (endogenous).

Option D: Acute primary angle-closure glaucoma presents with severe unilateral eye pain, associated with headache and loss of vision. The examination shows a red congested eye, corneal edema with a shallow anterior chamber, and a mid-dilated pupil.

questions.text: You work under a research scientist who is working on determining the association of mesothelioma with a compound, labeled compound X. He uses a test whose steps are shown in the image below to determine the mutagenic effect and potential carcinogenicity of compound X. What is this test that he has used?
questions.solution:
The image shows the Ames test.

Ames test is a widely used biological assay to assess the mutagenic potential of chemical compounds. It uses bacteria to test if the given chemical can cause mutations in the test organism's DNA. A positive test indicates that the chemical is mutagenic and therefore may act as a carcinogen because cancer is often linked to mutation.

The Ames test uses the principle of flocculation. Ames test does not determine the nature of carcinogenesis. The rationale of the test is that greater than 90% of all chemical mutagens are carcinogenic in subsequent animal tests. The bacterium used in the test is a strain of Salmonella typhimurium that carries a defective (mutant) gene making it unable to synthesize the amino acid histidine.

A drawback is that the compounds that alter epigenetic factors (such as DNA methylation) would test negative in the Ames test. 

Other options:

Option A: Comet assay is a single gel electrophoresis technique to measure DNA damage and repair at the individual cell level. Fragments of DNA pulled through agarose gel in an electric field will appear as a 'Comet.' It is generally used in human and ecological biomonitoring.

Option B: Micronucleus testing (MN test) is one of the valid tests used as a quick check for detection of acute disorders caused by chemical substances in cells that have undergone cell division. 

Option C: Microtox Bio-assay uses photo-luminescent bacteria to analyze acute chemical toxicity.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl has numerous vesicles on her face, particularly around her mouth as shown below. Over a few days, the vesicles turn into pustules and crust over, becoming flaky and light yellow in color. The girl's 40-year old uncle develops similar lesions after visiting for 1 week during the child's illness. Which of the following statements about the organism most likely responsible for this girl’s infection is correct?

choices.text: Sabouraud’s agar is required to culture this bacterium
The bacterium is a facultative intracellular organism
The bacterium is a group B β-hemolytic organism

questions.solution:
The history along with the image showing honey-crusted/ golden-crusted /yellowish-brown crusted lesions are characteristic of impetigo caused by Streptococcus pyogenes.

S. pyogenes is a gram-positive group A β-hemolytic organism that is bacitracin-sensitive. 

Impetigo is a contagious, superficial bacterial skin infection characterized by an eruption of vesicles on the face. These vesicles later turn into pustules with a characteristic honey-colored crust. It is very common in children, and in particular during summer. It spreads by direct contact with discharges from the scab of an infected person.

If it is mild, management includes removing crusts, washing skin using disinfectants. Topical antibiotics should be applied twice a day for a week.

If it has extensive skin involvement, bullous disease, or lymphadenopathy, treatment should include systemic antibiotics like flucloxacillin along with localized skin treatment.

Other options-

Option A- Sabouraud’s agar is required to culture fungi, not Streptococcus pyogenes.

Option B- Streptococcus pyogenes is not a facultative intracellular organisms. Mycobacterium, Brucella, Francisella, Listeria, Yersinia, Legionella, and Salmonella are a few examples of facultative intracellular organisms.

Option C- Streptococcus pyogenes is not a group B β-hemolytic organism. It is a group A β-hemolytic organism. Streptococcus agalactiae is a group B β-hemolytic organism.

c. Cellulitis- Infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It presents with erythema and edema. It can be differentiated from erysipelas by - i. Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is diagnosed to have Meniere's disease. He says he constantly gets vertiginous episodes when exposed to loud sounds. Which of the following term can be used to describe this symptom?
questions.solution:
Tullio phenomenon describes the vertiginous episodes associated with exposure to loud noise in a patient with Meniere's disease. This phenomenon is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis (drop attacks) is when a patient with Meniere’s develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness. It is an uncommon manifestation. Pathogenesis not well understood.

Lermoyez syndrome - Here symptoms of Meniere's disease are seen in reverse order. Initially, there is a progressive deterioration of hearing, followed by an attack of vertigo.

questions.text: What type of study is shown below?
questions.solution:
The study shown is a prospective cohort study. 

A cohort study is a type of analytical study, which progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occurred but not disease. It is also known as a forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study. It can be divided into:

  • Prospective cohort studies: Outcome has not occurred at the time of the beginning of the investigation 
  • Retrospective cohort studies: Outcome has occurred before the beginning of the investigation 
  • Combination cohort studies: Both retrospective and prospective elements are combined

A cohort is a group of individuals who share a common experience or characteristic within a defined time period. The cohort groups are selected before the appearance of the disease under investigation. They are divided into study and control cohorts. The study cohorts are exposed to a particular factor thought to be related to the disease occurrence whereas the control cohorts are not exposed to this particular factor.  

Studying the effects of exposure to uranium in causing lung cancer is an example of a cohort study. Uranium miners are taken as the study cohort and other individuals who are not exposed to uranium mining are taken as the control cohort. 

Note: In a nested case-control study, cases of disease that have occurred in a defined cohort are identified. A specified number of matched controls who have not developed the disease are then selected from the cohort. 

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: A newborn was found to have a following anomaly of the penile urethra while being examined by a pediatrician. Identify the incorrect statement regarding the condition.

choices.text: It is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra
Circumcision should be done to remove the excess skin
It does not cause urinary obstruction
Ventral chordee is a common association

questions.solution:
The image showing a newborn having a urethral meatus that opens on the underside of the penis is indicative of hypospadias. Circumcision should not be done in hypospadias as the foreskin will be used for surgical reconstruction.

Hypospadias is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. It is characterized by the combination of:

  • A ventrally placed urethral meatus (underside of penis or perineum)
  • Poor development of the ventral aspect of the prepuce (resulting in hooded foreskin)
  • Ventral chordee (bending of the penis)

Hypospadias does not cause either obstruction or urinary tract infection and surgery is recommended for sexual, urinary stream, or cosmetic reasons. 

Note: In hypospadias, ventral chordee is seen, whereas, in epispadias, dorsal chordee is seen.

questions.text: During the evaluation of a psychiatric patient, the psychiatrist asks her the meaning of proverbs like a stitch in time saves nine, and similarities between a chair, table, and sofa. What is the doctor assessing?
questions.solution:
Similarities or differences between things, meanings of proverbs are asked during the assessment of abstract thinking of the patient.

Other options:

Option A- Test judgment is assessed by asking the patient what he would do in hypothetical situations, such as what the patient would do if he sees a house on fire, or what the patient would do if he sees a sealed, stamped, addressed envelope lying on a street.

Option C- Social judgment is the ability to perceive social situations and act accordingly. It is assessed by observing if the behavior of the patient is appropriate or not, if it is causing any harm to the patient, or is not acceptable by society.

Option D- Insight is the degree of personal awareness and understanding of the disease. It can have 5 grades. 

  1. Complete denial of illness.
  2. Slight awareness of being sick and needing help but denying it at the same time.
  3. Awareness of being sick, but is attributed to external, physical factors or unknown factors.
  4. Intellectual insight- Awareness of being ill, and that the symptoms are due to own particular irrational feelings and thoughts. However, this knowledge is not applied to future behavior.
  5. Emotional insight-Awareness of being ill, and that the symptoms are due to own particular irrational feelings and thoughts. The patient also makes significant changes in the personality and future behavior.

Related Pearl: Tests for evaluating attention, concentration and memory

Memory:

Memory is of 3 types:

  • Immediate memory and recall are usually tested by digit span/ digit repetition test.
    • Digit span test: Digits spelled at the rate of 1 digit per second. It is of two types: Digit forward and Digit backward.
    • Digit forward: Reproduction of increasingly longer digits. E.g., Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat in the same order 2 – 4 – 8 –1 –5 –7 –9.
    • Digit backward: Reproduction of longer digits in the backward direction. Eg: Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat it backward. 9 -7 -5 -1 -8- 4- 2.
    • The above tests should be stopped when there are 2 successive failures. Hence 2 skips are not allowed.
  • Recent memory: Ask them how they reached the hospital or what they ate for breakfast.
  • Remote memory: Relevant questions from the past like close relative's birth dates. 

Attention:

  • Is the patient's attention easily aroused and sustained?
  • Digit span test.

Concentration:

  • Is the patient easily distractable or can they concentrate?
  • Serial subtraction test: Minimum of five subtractions done serially is taken into account
  • Count backward from 20.
  • Enumerate the months in reverse order.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presented to the OPD with purplish, itchy, flat-topped bumps on his shins along with a fine reticular lacy pattern on the oral mucosa as shown in the below image. Which of the following nail changes is most specific in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of purplish, itchy, flat-topped lesions on shins and white streaks forming a lacework in the buccal mucosa, Wickham's striae, shown in the image are diagnostic of Lichen planus. Among all the nail changes seen in Lichen planus, Dorsal nail pterygium is the most specific nail finding.

The most common presentation of lichen planus is a well-defined area of purple-colored, itchy, flat-topped papules with interspersed lacy white lines known as Wickham's striae. This description is known as the characteristic "6 Ps" of lichen planus: planar (flat-topped), purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules, and plaques.

The main treatment in the case of persistent lichen planus is steroids. The first line of therapy is always topical steroids. The second-line treatment is with systemic steroids, retinoids, and PUVA.

Other options:

Option B: Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon patch is a pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. 

Option C and D: Pup tent sign and thinning of the nail plate are the nail findings seen in lichen planus.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image: Trachyonychia

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)
